intro: Chenopodium ambrosioides var. obovatum, commonly known as wild gooseberry, is a herbaceous annual plant native to North America. It features alternate, ovate to obovate leaves that are usually covered in fine, glandular hairs. The plant produces small, greenish flowers arranged in compact clusters, followed by edible, tangy berries that are often used in culinary applications. It thrives in disturbed soils and is commonly found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. This species is also known for its medicinal properties and has been used traditionally in herbal remedies.
